I.  

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People's  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  Subregional  Transport  Project  Preparatory 
Facility. 
 
2. 
The  proposed  technical  assistance  loan  will  provide  the  facility  to  prepare  a  series  of 
regional cooperation and integration (RCI) transport projects in roads and railways. The loan will 
ensure  the  projects  are  ready  for  implementation  by  providing  funding  for  feasibility  studies, 
detailed design preparation, procurement assistance, and safeguard implementation. The focus 
will  be  on  priority  transport  corridors  identified  in  the  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional 
Cooperation  (SAARC)  Regional  Multimodal  Transport  Study.1 Transport  corridors  linking  with 
the Bay of Bengal Initiative for Multi-Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC) 
countries2 —such as the Asian Highway Network and the Trans-Asia Rail Network—will also be 
targeted. While the facility will cover 8% of Bangladesh's major roads and 12% of its railways, 
development  of  these  corridors  would  complete  the  subregional  land  transport  network,  which 
will stimulate both subregional trade and the Bangladesh economy.  
 

II.  

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Although South Asia has been one of the fastest-growing economic regions in the world, 
intraregional  trade  accounts  for  only  about  5%  of  total  trade  in  the  region.  By  comparison, 
intraregional trade accounts for 26% of total trade in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN), 52% of total trade in North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) countries, and 
58%  of total trade  in  the  European  Union. The  South  Asian  Free Trade Area  is  slowly  getting 
implemented while bilateral free trade agreements have also been demonstrating encouraging 
increase  to  trade  volumes.  However,  investment  in  the  region  needs  to  be  accelerated, 
particularly in less-developed areas such as Bangladesh. 
 
4. 
Countries  with  well-developed  and  integrated  transport  and  communications  systems 
tend to  attract more foreign direct  investment. Integrated  transport  systems  improve  access  to 
subregional markets, making structural changes in their production capacities that can expand 
and  diversify  the  basket  of  goods  available  for  export.  This  is  essential  to  transforming  the 
fortunes of the smaller economies of South Asia. 
 
5. 
Bangladesh  has  the  potential  to  become  a  transport  and  transshipment  center  for  the 
subregion.  It  borders  India  and  Myanmar  and  is  geographically  close  to  Bhutan,  Nepal,  and 
Kunming—the key transportation hub in southwest People’s Republic of China (PRC). With the 
opening of the Bhangabandhu Bridge over the Jamuna River (the Jamuna Multipurpose Bridge) 
and the proposed development of the Padma Bridge, the Dhaka–Chittagong transport corridor 
and  other  strategic  transport  corridors  can  facilitate  trade  between  Bangladesh  and  the 
northeastern  states  of  India,  the  Indian  state  of  West  Bengal,  Bhutan,  and  Nepal,  thereby 
attracting more foreign and domestic investment to the country.

 While overall trade in Bangladesh has increased since economic liberalization in 1980’s 
6. 
and  its  acceleration  in  1990’s,  exports to  East  Asia  (6.8%)  and  South  Asia  (1.6%)  continue  to 
account  for  a  small  share  of  overall  trade.  A  2008  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  study3 
identified  weak  trade-related  infrastructure  and  poor  connectivity  are  one  of  the  more  serious 
impediments  to  expansion  of  trade  and  investment  among  countries,  in  addition  to  a  narrow 
export  base  and  few  complementarities  with  other  countries  in  the  region.  Another  study—the 
BIMSTEC  Transport  Infrastructure  and  Logistics  Study4—determined  that  improved  transport 
infrastructure and improved access to modern transport systems are the keys to enhancing RCI 
in Bangladesh. 
 
7. 
Because  of  its  location,  Bangladesh  plays  a  key  role  in  RCI.  The  SAARC  Regional 
Multimodal Transport Study identified priority corridors among SAARC countries. Six out of 10 
priority  road  corridors  and  two  out  of  five  priority  rail  corridors  go  through  Bangladesh. 
Bangladesh  also  has  two  of  the  priority  ports  (Chittagong  and  Mongla)  providing  international 
gateways  for  international  trade.  Bangladesh  requires  massive  investment  to  improve 
infrastructure  along  these  priority  corridors.  Such  investment  would  not  only  contribute  to  the 
development  of  Bangladesh's  own  economy,  but  would  also  contribute  heavily  to  increasing 
subregional trade. 
 
8. 
The proposed technical assistance loan would focus the country’s transport investment 
effectively  on  these  subregional  transport  infrastructure  projects  that  will  have  national  as  well 
as  subregional  economic  impacts.  To  promote  RCI,  these  subregional  transport  infrastructure 
projects  need  to  be  ready  for  implementation.  The  proposed  loan  will  immediately  support 
government initiatives to develop subregional projects in the wake of recent summits with India 
and  the  People's  Republic  of  China.  Indicative  follow-on  RCI  loans  in  transport  are  already 
envisioned in the ADB’s South Asia regional cooperation strategy,5 which is in line with priorities 
outlined  in  the  SAARC  Regional  Multimodal  Transport  Study  and  the  Transport  Infrastructure 
and Logistics Study undertaken by BIMSTEC. 
 
9. 
The proposed facility will also address two key problems related to ADB's involvement in 
transport  infrastructure  that  were  mentioned  in  the  country  assistance  program  evaluation  for 
Bangladesh6 in  October  2009:  (i)  land  acquisition  and  procurement  delays,  and  (ii)  start-up 
delays.  These  problems  were  caused  by  the  project  design  where  detailed  design,  usually 
financed by the loan itself, starts long after loan approval). One of the major recommendations 
of  the  country  assistance  program  evaluation  was  to  reduce  start-up  delays  by  ensuring  that 
transport projects are ready for implementation shortly after loan approval. 
 
10. 
 
B. 
 
11. 
The  impact  of  the  facility  will  be  to  increase  subregional  trade  among  South  Asian 
countries,  especially  from,  to,  and  through  Bangladesh.  The  outcome  of  the  facility  will  be  to 
improve  implementation  efficiency  of  RCI  land  transport  projects  and  promote  investments  to 
RCI projects by other development partners and the government.

Roads and Highways Department component. For the selected RCI road subprojects, 
the  facility  will  provide:  (i)  a  feasibility  study,  if  required,  and  detailed  design;  (ii) safeguard 
implementation  and  procurement support,  and  (iii) capacity  development support  to the  Roads 
and Highways Department (RHD) to enhance RHD operational efficiency and governance. The 
RCI  road  subprojects  selected  for  preparation  under  this  component  of  the  facility  shall  target 
priority  roads  that  have  substantial  RCI  impacts,  including  SAARC  road  corridors  identified  in 
the SAARC Regional Multimodal Transport Study and Asian Highways network.7 Although most 
subprojects  shall  be  those  already  identified,  should  any  replacement  or  supplemental 
subprojects  be  proposed  for  inclusion  after  Board  approval,  these  may  be  considered  if  they 
satisfy  agreed  criteria,  including  in  particular  the  requirement  that  they  have  substantial 
subregional  implications.8   In  principle,  all  roads  will  be  designed  as  four-lane,  but  the  final 
design  will  depend  on  the  feasibility  study,  taking  into  account  engineering,  economic,  social, 
and  environmental  viability.  Consultants  will  also  explore  possible  private–public  partnerships 
for financially viable subprojects. Capacity development support will improve the RHD's internal 
control  mechanisms,  asset  management  systems,  business  procedures,  and  human  resource 
management. The facility aims to prepare at least 300 km for tendering in 2012, and an overall 
approximate length of 1,700 km by end of 2013. 
 
Bangladesh Railway component. For selected RCI railway subprojects, the facility will

Consultants  will  be  recruited  to  prepare  feasibility  studies  and  detailed  design  for 
14. 
selected subprojects, as well as provide assistance with procurement. Safeguard consultants in 
the  fields  of  resettlement,  social  aspects,  and  environment  will  also  be  engaged  to  (i)  provide 
support  on  safeguards  planning,  implementation,  and  capacity  development;  (ii)  facilitate 
effective  coordination  among  relevant  stakeholders;  and  (iii)  monitor  implementation  of 
safeguard plans. Capacity development consultants will be engaged to work with RHD staff to 
update and utilize the financial management systems and asset management systems.9

18. 
To  avoid  start-up  delays,  the government  has  requested that  ADB  carry  out  consultant 
selection  on  its  behalf.  The  government  will  retain  its  authority  for  contract  negotiation  and 
contract  signing.  The  recent  summit  agreement  between  Bangladesh  and  India  requires  the 
government  to  move  forward  on  significant  RCI  projects.  This  is  in  line  with  ADB's  long-term 
strategy  to  promote  RCI.  To  further  accelerate  the  development  of  RCI  projects,  quality 
consultants should be engaged in a timely manner.  
 

III.  

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic 

 
A. 
 
The  follow-on  transport  investments  prepared  under  the  proposed  facility  will  support 
19. 
Bangladesh's economic growth and reduce poverty by connecting major markets in the country 
and providing communities with access to economic and social services. It will also contribute to 
regional  cooperation  and  integration  by  strengthening  connectivity  with  neighboring  countries 
and  increasing  trade  competitiveness  of  Bangladesh.  A  preliminary  study  on  transit  traffic 

5 

 

 Governance 

through  Bangladesh 11  estimates  that  the  improvement  of  Bangladeshi  sections  of  priority 
subregional transport corridors could facilitate the movement of about 18 million tons of freight 
in Bhutan, India, and Nepal.   
 
The proposed facility will combine support for project feasibility studies, detailed design, 
20. 
procurement, and safeguard implementation, ensuring that (i) follow-on investment projects will 
be  implemented  without  delay,  (ii)  the  positive  impacts  of  follow-on  investment  projects  will 
materialize  without  delay,  and  (iii)  the  government  will  minimize  commitment  and  interest 
charges arising under follow-on loans. The facility will help the government ensure the economic 
and financial viability of transport corridor projects with subregional impacts, and will mitigate the 
social and environmental risks of any follow-on projects. 
 
By  providing  detailed  design,  procurement,  and  safeguard  implementation  support 
21. 
immediately after the feasibility study, the proposed facility will accelerate the commencement of 
physical works of the follow-on loans by at least 1 year compared with projects processed under 
conventional schemes. Currently, project executing agencies in Bangladesh can start recruiting 
consultants only after the project loans have been approved. By contrast, the proposed facility 
will  allow  executing  agencies  to  undertake  detailed  design  immediately  after  completion  of 
feasibility studies. 
 
B. 
 
22. 
Financial  management.  Both  the  RHD  and  Bangladesh  Railway  have  prior  and 
ongoing  experience  with  implementing  ADB-funded  projects,  and  have  knowledge  of  project 
financial accounting methods and ADB disbursement procedures. For the proposed facility, one 
accountant  will  be  included  in  each  project  implementation  unit.  The  RHD  and  Bangladesh 
Railway  have  participated  in  workshops  run  by  ADB  consultants  on  good  practice  of  financial 
management systems. 
 
23. 
The RHD and Bangladesh Railway will establish and maintain separate project records 
and  accounts  to  identify  the  finances  received  and  expenditures  made  under  the  facility, 
ensuring  an  adequate  audit  trail.  The  accounts  will  be  set  up  in  accordance  with  sound 
accounting  principles.  Independent  auditors,  acceptable  to  ADB,  will  audit  the  accounts  and 
related financial statements annually.  
 
24. 
Procurement  and  anticorruption.  Recruitment  of  consultants  will  be  carried  out  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  ADB  will  select  the  consultants  and  the  executing  agencies  will  negotiate  and  contract 
with the consultants thus selected (refer to para 18). This recruitment process will help to ensure 
that consulting services are available in a timely manner. The procurement rules for selection of 
contractors  required  by  international  financial  institutions  such  as  the  ADB  are  considered 
sufficiently robust to deter corruption at the bid selection stage. National procurement regulation 
has  also  improved  recently  through  the  Public  Procurement  Act,  2006,  and  through  related 
Public Procurement Rules (2008) with subsequent amendments. During implementation of the 
facility,  reports  will  be  submitted  to  executing  agencies  and  ADB  in  line  with  submission 
milestones to ensure the quality and timeliness of consultants' work.

The  proposed  facility  will  ensure  development  of  environmentally  and  socially  viable

Follow-on  projects  will  be  designed  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
(2009)  and government guidelines,  regulations, and  policies.  During the feasibility  studies,  the 
consultants  will  prepare  environmental 
initial  environmental 
examinations,  as  applicable,  including  environmental  management  plans  for  the  selected 
subprojects. Similarly, resettlement planning, indigenous peoples planning, and gender analysis 
will be prepared for the selected subprojects during this stage. 
 
D. 
 
The  facility  is  not  expected  to  have  any  impacts  on  gender  and  social  dimensions.

Dimensions in Projects and Handbook on Social Analysis.12 Gender, labor, HIV/AIDS, and other 
social risks related to follow-on loans will be assessed, and a mitigation plan will be prepared to 
address those issues.

28.  Major  risks  associated  with  implementing  the  facility  were  identified  and  practical 
measures  were  assessed  as  appropriate.  To  minimize  delay  in  mobilization  of  consultants, 
selection will be undertaken by ADB on behalf of the government. Emphasis is put on quality in 
the  selection  process  and  the  contract  is  packaged  in  a  large  size  to  ensure  engagement  of 
quality consultants. For timely and quality report submission by consultants, executing agencies 
have  set  up  teams  to  review  consultants'  reports.  Reports  will  also  be  submitted  to  ADB  for 
review  and  quality  check.  Strong  internal  control  is  ensured  in  financial  management  by 
adopting a direct payment procedure. Progress payment will be made in line with the payment 
schedule after quality check by executing agencies and ADB.
